automobilesGeneral.Title: Automobiles
automobilesGeneral.Body: An automobile is a wheeled motor vehicle used for transportation (Car, 2019). Most definitions of cars say that they run primarily on roads, seat one to eight people, have four tires, and mainly transport people rather than goods (Car, 2019). Cars came into global use during the 20th century, and developed economies depend on them (Car, 2019). The year 1886 is regarded as the birth year of the modern car when German inventor Karl Benz patented his Benz Patent-Motorwagen (Car, 2019). Cars became widely available in the early 20th century. One of the first cars accessible to the masses was the 1908 Model T, an American car manufactured by the Ford Motor Company (Car, 2019). Cars were rapidly adopted in the US, where they replaced animal-drawn carriages and carts, but took much longer to be accepted in Western Europe and other parts of the world (Car, 2019). Electric cars, which were invented early in the history of the car, became commercially available in the 2000s and are predicted to cost less to buy than gasoline cars before 2025 (Car, 2019). There are costs and benefits to car use. The costs to the individual include acquiring the vehicle, interest payments (if the car is financed), repairs and maintenance, fuel, depreciation, driving time, parking fees, taxes, and insurance (Car, 2019). The costs to society include maintaining roads, land use, road congestion, air pollution, public health, health care, and disposing of the vehicle at the end of its life. Traffic collisions are the largest cause of injury-related deaths worldwide (Car, 2019). The personal benefits include on-demand transportation, mobility, independence, and convenience. The societal benefits include economic benefits, such as job and wealth creation from the automotive industry, transportation provision, societal well-being from leisure and travel opportunities, and revenue generation from taxes. People’s ability to move flexibly from place to place has far-reaching implications for the nature of societies. There are around 1 billion cars in use worldwide. These numbers are increasing rapidly, especially in China, India and other newly industrialized countries (Car, 2019).

Questions.Question: The year 1886 is regarded as the birth year of the modern car when…?
Options: German inventor Karl Benz patented his Benz Patent-Motorwagen
Italian Enzo Ferrari made the Ferrari 125 S !
American Henry Ford introduced the Ford Model T

Questions.Question: Which car was first available to the masses?
What is not a benefit of motorcar use?
Options: Economic benefits, such as job and wealth creation from the automotive industry

historicalAutomobiles.Title: 17th 18th and 19th Century Vehicles
historicalAutomobiles.Body: Most historians agree that Nicolas-Joseph Cugnot of France was the constructor of the first true automobile. Cugnot’s vehicle was a huge, heavy, steam-powered tricycle, and his model of 1769 was said to have run for 20 minutes at 2.25 miles (3.6 km) per hour while carrying four people and to have recuperated sufficient steam power to move again after standing for 20 minutes. Cugnot was an artillery officer, and the steam-tight positions of his engine were made possible by the invention of a drill that accurately machined cannon bores. A replica of Cugnot’s second vehicle, partially original, is preserved in the Conservatoire National des Arts et Metiers in Paris.

Questions.Question: Who constructed the first true automobile?

electricAutomobiles.Title: Early Electric Automobiles
electricAutomobiles.Body: Sources point to different creations as the first electric car. Between 1832 and 1839 (the exact year is uncertain) Robert Anderson of Scotland invented a crude electric carriage, powered by non-rechargeable primary cells (History of the automobile, 2019). In November 1881, French inventor Gustave Trouve demonstrated a working three wheeled car powered by electricity at the International Exposition of Electricity, Paris (History of the automobile, 2019). English inventor Thomas Parker, who was responsible for innovations such as electrifying the London Underground, overhead tramways in Liverpool and Birmingham, and the smokeless fuel coalite, built the first production electric car in London in 1884, using his own specially designed high-capacity rechargeable batteries (History of the automobile, 2019). But others regard the Flocken Elektrowagen of 1888 by German inventor Andreas Flocken as the first true electric car (History of the automobile, 2019). Electric cars enjoyed popularity between the late 19th century and early 20th century, when electricity was among the preferred methods for automobile propulsion, providing a level of comfort and ease of operation that could not be achieved by the gasoline cars of the time. Advances in internal combustion technology, especially the electrical starter, soon rendered this advantage moot; the greater range of gasoline cars, quicker refueling times, and growing petroleum infrastructure, along with the mass production of gasoline vehicles by companies such as the Ford Motor Company, which reduced prices of gasoline cars to less than half that of equivalent electric cars, led to a decline in the use of electric propulsion, effectively removing it from important markets such as the United States by the 1930s (History of the automobile, 2019).

Questions.Question: Many others regard this car designed by this man to be the first electric automobile…
Options: the Flocken Elektrowagen of 1888 by German inventor Andreas Flocken
French inventor Gustave Trouve’s working three wheeled car
the London Underground, overhead tramways’ car

Questions.Question: When were electric cars popular (not including today)
Options: between the late 19th century and early 20th century
between the late 18th century and early 19th century
between the late 17th century and early 18th century

internalCombustion.Title: Internal Combustion Engines
internalCombustion.Body: Early attempts at making and using internal combustion engines were hampered by the lack of suitable fuels, particularly liquids, therefore the earliest engines used gas mixtures (History of the automobile, 2019).Early experimenters used gases. In 1806, Swiss engineer Francois Isaac de Rivaz built an engine powered by internal combustion of a hydrogen and oxygen mixture (History of the automobile, 2019). In 1826, Englishman Samuel Brown tested his hydrogen-fuelled internal combustion engine by using it to propel a vehicle up Shooter’s Hill in south-east London (History of the automobile, 2019). Belgian-born Etienne Lenoir’s Hippomobile with a hydrogen-gas-fuelled one-cylinder internal combustion engine made a test drive from Paris to Joinville-le-Point in 1860, covering some nine kilometers in three hours. A later version was propelled by coal gas. In about 1870, in Vienna, Austria (then the Austro-Hungarian Empire) x put a liquid-fuelled internal combustion engine on a simple handcart which made him the first man to propel a vehicle by means of gasoline. Today, this car is known as the first Marcus car. In 1883, Marcus secured a German patent for a low voltage ignition system of the magneto type; this was his only automotive patent. The design was used for all further engines, and the four-seat second Marcus car of 1888/89 (History of the automobile, 2019). This ignition, in conjunction with the rotating-brush carburetor, made the second car’s design very innovative. His second car is on display at the Technical Museum in Vienna. During his lifetime he was honored as the originator of the motorcar but his place in history was all but erased by the Nazis during World War II. Because Marcus was of Jewish descent, the Nazi propaganda office ordered his work to be destroyed, his name expunged from future textbooks, and his public memorials removed, giving credit instead to Karl Benz (History of the automobile, 2019). It is generally acknowledged that the first really practical automobiles with petrol/gasoline powered internal combustion engines were completed almost simultaneously by several inventors working independently: Karl Benz built his first automobile in 1885 in Mannheim. Benz was granted a patent for his automobile on 29 January 1886, and began the first production of automobiles in 1888, after Bertha Benz, his wife, had proved – with the first long-distance trip in August 1888, from Mannheim to Pforzheim and back – that the horseless coach was capable of extended travel (History of the automobile, 2019). Soon after, Gottlieb Daimler and Wilhelm Maybach in Stuttgart in 1889 designed a vehicle from scratch to be an automobile, rather than a horse-drawn carriage fitted with an engine.

Questions.Question: What is the name of the inventor who’s work the Nazi’s tried to discredit?

firstAffordableCar.Title: The First Affordable Car
firstAffordableCar.Body: The Ford Model T is an automobile produced by Ford Motor Company for October 1, 1908 to May 26, 1927. It is generally regarded as the first affordable automobile, the car that opened travel to the common middle class American; some of this was because of Ford’s efficient fabrication, including assembly line production instead of individual hand crafting (Ford Model T, 2019). With 16.5 million sold it stands eighth on the top ten list od the most sold cars of all time as of 2012 (Ford Model T, 2019).

Questions.Question: When was the Ford Model T produced?
How many Ford Model T’s were sold?

bugattiType35.Title: The Bugatti Type 35
bugattiType35.Body: The Type 35 was the most successful of the Bugatti racing models. The type 35 was phenomenally successful, winning over 1000 races in its time. It took the Grand Prix World Championship in 1926 after winning 351 races and setting 47 records in the two prior years. At its height, Type 35s averaged 14 races per wins per week (Bugatti Type 35, 2019).

Questions.Question: How many races did the Bugatti Type 35 win?

volkswagenBeetle.Title: The Volkswagen Beetle
volkswagenBeetle.Body: The Volkswagen Beetle is a two door, rear engine economy car, intended for five occupants that was manufactured and marketed by German automaker Volkswagen from 1938 until 2003. The need for a people’s car (Volkswagen in German), its concept and functional objectives were formulated by the leader of Nazi Germany, Adolf Hitler, who wanted a cheap, simple car to be mass-produced for his country’s new road network (Volkswagen Beetle, 2019). With 21, 529, 464 produced, the Beetle is the longest-running and most manufactured car of a single platform ever made.

Questions.Question: Which leader commissioned the Volkswagen Beetle?
How many Volkswagen Beetles were made?

mini.Title: The Mini
mini.Body: The Mini is a small economy car produced by the English-based British Motor Company (BMC) and its successors from 1959 until 2000. The original is considered an icon of 1960s British popular culture. Its space saving transverse engine and front-wheel drive layout – allowing 80% of the area of the car’s floorpan to be used for passengers and luggage – influenced a generation of car makers (Mini, 2019). The performance versions, the Mini Cooper and Cooper “S” were successful as both race and rally cars, winning the Monte Carlo Rally in 1964, 1965, and 1967. In 1966, the first-placed Mini (along with nine other cars) was disqualified after the finish after a controversial decision that the car’s headlights were against the rules (Mini, 2019).

Questions.Question: How did the mini save space in its engineering?
Options: A transverse engine and front-wheel drive
An inverse engine and rear-wheel drive

Questions.Question: What years did the Mini Cooper and Cooper S win the Monte Carlo Rally

bugattiChiron.Title: Bugatti Chiron
bugattiChiron.Body: The Bugatti Chiron is a mid-engine two-seater sports car developed and manufactured in Molsheim, France by French automobile manufacturer Bugatti Automobiles S.A.S. as the successor to the Bugatti Veyron. The main carry over component from the Veyron is the 7,993 cc (8.0 L) quad-turbocharged W16 engine, though it is heavily updated. The engine in the Chiron has a peak power output of 1,479 hp (Bugatti Chiron, 2019). The Chiron can accelerate from 0–97 km/h (0–60 mph) in 2.4 seconds according to the manufacturer (Bugatti Chiron, 2019). The Chiron's top speed is electronically limited to 420 km/h (261 mph), for safety reasons, mainly arising from the tires as the manufacturer concluded that no tire currently manufactured would be able to handle the stress at the top speed the Chiron is capable of achieving (Bugatti Chiron, 2019). The base price is €2,400,000 and buyers were required to place a €200,000 deposit before their purchase (Bugatti Chiron, 2019).

Questions.Question: What does a Bugatti Chiron cost?
What is the zero to 60 mph time of a Bugatti Chiron?

teslaModel3.Title: Tesla Model 3
teslaModel3.Body: The Tesla Model 3 is an electric four-door sedan developed by Tesla (Tesla Model 3, 2019). The Model 3 Standard Range Plus version delivers an EPA-rated all-electric range of 250 miles (402 km) and the Long Range versions deliver 322 miles (518 km) (Tesla Model 3, 2019). The Model 3 carries full self-driving hardware, with periodic software updates adding additional functionality. Within a week of unveiling the Model 3 in 2016, Tesla revealed they had taken 325, 000 reservations for the car. These reservations represented potential sales of over US $14 billion. Limited production of the Model 3 began in mid-2017, with the first production vehicle rolling off the assembly line on July 7, 2017, with the official launch and delivery of the first 30 cars on July 28 (Tesla Model 3, 2019). On July 1, 2018, it was announced that Tesla had met its production goal of 5,000 cars in a week (Tesla Model 3, 2019). In February 2019, the Model 3 passed the Chevrolet Volt to become the all-time best selling plug-in electric car in the US  (Tesla Model 3, 2019).

Questions.Question: What is the range of a long range version of a Tesla Model 3?
Within a week of unveiling the Tesla Model 3 how many reservations were there for the car?

mainPage.Title: Time to Learn the History of the Automobile!
mainPage.Body:
Go through all the topics at your own pace using the navbar above!
At the end of each section there will be a quiz asking some simple questions about the section! While doing this quiz, you wont be able to look at the page, so make sure to keep note of anything important!
 Once you have gotten through all the sections you can select the quiz me button at the top right corner! This will start the main quiz!
 Once started, you will get 3 chances to revisit pages incase you get stuck! So make sure to use them sparingly!

 Have fun!

Sources: Ford Model T. (2019, November 13). Retrieved from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Model_T.
History of the automobile. (2019, November 15). Retrieved from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_automobile.
